projects i've worked on

ktracker

KTracker is a bug tracking application I developed to help with a program called Kraken that we used in the warehouse at my previous job. It is a simple bug and feature request tracker that allows for multiple users and storing and exporting reports from the DB.

I used ReactJS for the front end, Node/ExpressJS for the back end, as well as various tools such as React Router, SQLite, and Babel.

KTracker was the first back-end I built and I learned a ton from it. I built a basic CRUD API with Express, dabbled in SQL for the database for the first time, and implemented user credential validation.

Github

sought tech skills

Sought Tech Skills is a little web scraper app that will search through Indeed.com and StackOverflow Jobs and search for key words relating to programming languages and frameworks and returns the popularity of said keywords by percentage in the selected city.

I took advantage of Python3 and its libraries Flask and beautiful soup.

This project was originally going to be a command line app, but I decided to try out Flask with this project. Main takeaways included basic data manipulation, basic html templating usage, and basic scraping knowledge.

Github

spotify genre playlist generator

This is a command line program that takes a users Spotify library and runs it through the Gracenote API to sort it into the proper genre playlist and creates said playlists on the user's account.

The tools I used to finish this project were Python3, the Spofify API and the Gracenote API.

I learned a good amount on APIs, data structuring and manipulation, and API authentication.

Github

codesandbox.io

Linked is my codesandbox.io account. I have a few projects up there, including a few React components that I am proud of. It is also the home of my own CSS Zen Garden and a couple other half baked projects. Also linked is my codepen.io profile, where you will find mostly CSS based exercises that I completed.

The projects I have listed mainly use React and basic html, js, and css. On my codepen profile, there are maybe 10 or so pens that are pure HTML and CSS.

Working on codesandbox.io and codepen.io led me to code nearly everyday and stretch my practical web developement knowledge.
